entry.title: Re: Impact on the processes
entry.content:
Impact of this set up

Cost Storage & Reporting
Estimated costs, planned costs, and baseline costs will each be stored in their own dedicated plan category. Reports in CO (e.g. cost comparison, variance analysis) will pull values from these categories. This improves clarity because each type of cost has its own “bucket.”

Integration with PM Orders
When you create or change a maintenance order, estimated costs (from order costing) go into PMORDER01. Planned costs (from manually planned activities/materials) go into PMORDER02. Baseline costs (reference snapshot for comparison) go into PMORDER03. This ensures consistency in how costs are tracked and compared.

Restrictions
Because you set “No specific usage” and disallow import/copy/delete, these plan categories cannot be reused in other applications (e.g. projects, cost centers). They are locked to maintenance orders only. You cannot copy values between categories or import external plans into them.

Irreversibility
Once you assign PMORDER01/02/03 to estimated/planned/baseline in customizing, you cannot later reassign them to different roles. If you later decide you want a different plan category for “planned costs,” you would need to create new categories and reconfigure, but historical data would remain in the old ones. This has long-term reporting implications.

Reporting & Analytics
Standard CO reports (e.g. Order: Planned/Actual/Variance) will show values based on these categories. If you later want to consolidate or compare across applications, you may find these categories isolated. Custom reporting may be needed if you want to analyze across multiple plan categories.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Procure to Order 2602 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Community, and welcome to our 2602 Key Innovations blog.
In this post, we’re sharing some key updates included in the Q1 2026 release in the procure to order space.

The focus this release covers flexibility in the Guided Buying RFQ process as well as ability to import contracts into SAP Ariba guided buying to help drive greater overall contract compliance and in turn more realised savings.

 

Use Standard Shipping Address for Request for Quotes in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-1267)

Based on the type of item and category, your organization may allow you to request a quote from one or more suppliers as the logical, stramlined process.

With this feature we have introduced more flexibility to select the ship-to address in the RFQ process in guided buying, you can now configure guided buying to either:

Display the user's default ship-to address on RFQ’s generated through guided buying (this is the default option)

Or

Allow users to choose an alternate shipping address for RFQ’s if better aligned to your companies processes

In order to do this a new parameter needs to be enabled by your system administrator: (PARAM_ENABLE_RFQ_SHIP_TO_ADDRESS_IN_USER_CHOSEN_ENTITY)

 

Import Purchase Contracts into SAP Ariba Buying Solutions  (ACC-267)

This feature enables buyers to import purchase contracts from SAP S/4HANA into SAP Ariba buying solutions as a customer configured option using the corresponding parameter ‘Automatic approval of contract requests sent using web services’

In SAP Ariba buying solutions, you can publish non-catalog items in the contract compliance module, which generates subscriptions for those items to make them available in the catalog search to help drive contract compliance.

The import utilizes web services capability in SAP Integration Suite, Managed Gateway for Spend Management and SAP Business Network, which connects SAP S/4HANA and SAP Ariba buying solutions.

For more related technical information you can also refer to:

Integration Support to Import Purchase Contracts from SAP ERP to SAP Ariba Buying Solutions via Web Services

Automatic approval of contract requests sent using web services.

 

Enable Users to Join the SAP User Research Panel (GUIDEB-1259)

With this feature, respondents of the user experience survey in guided buying can provide additional feedback by joining the SAP User Research Panel.

This allows a continuous feedback mechanism where it’s needed, in the application.

This in turn will help SAP product teams to collect continuous feedback and further focus the innovation Roadmap where its important.

This feature introduces changes to the user experience survey. Now, after users complete the survey, a thank you message and an option to join the SAP User Research Panel displays.

 

We hope these features will provide a blend of enhancements that will help to streamline process, increase adoption and add valuable feedback channels into SAP Product. Thanks for reading.

 

Resources:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement and Network
  • What’s New

entry.title: SBTi Forest, Land, and Agriculture (FLAG) in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
entry.content:
As companies work towards meeting their climate targets, the distinction between fossil and land-based emissions is becoming increasingly relevant. Emissions from forests, land, and agriculture (FLAG) follow fundamentally different dynamics than those from fossil fuels and materials. FLAG emissions have a significant share in global greenhouse gas emissions, play a critical role in climate mitigation, biodiversity protection, and food system resilience, which provides several advantages in environmental impact mitigation within value chains.

However, these emissions are often bundled together with Fossil GHG Emissions within corporate inventories without the level of detail to credibly manage them. This makes it difficult for companies to set realistic targets, assess progress, or transparently communicate the role of land-based emissions and removals within their GHG inventories. 

When properly understood as part of the natural carbon cycle, FLAG emissions become an important part of net-zero strategies: They are governed by biological processes that allows them to interact directly with removals and carbon storage within shorter timeframes compared to Fossil emissions. 

Against this backdrop, the latest updates to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management mark a significant evolution from a single-impact focus to a holistic environmental footprint analysis. The new capabilities expand impact coverage and explicitly distinguish between fossil and biogenic emissions and removals, enabling companies to reflect land-based dynamics more accurately. 

 Why distinguishing FLAG emissions matters at corporate and product level 

Distinguishing FLAG emissions from Fossil emissions is not just an accounting exercise. At the corporate level, separating FLAG from non-FLAG emissions allows companies to determine whether they are required to set dedicated FLAG targets under certain criteria and to incorporate mitigation pathways that reflect the realities of land-based systems.  

At the Corporate level, this differentiation enables a more realistic target setting, prevents the inappropriate use or double counting of removals within corporate inventories, supports transparent reporting, and progress toward emissions reductions. Without this separation, land use impacts can get hidden behind corporate totals, making progress appear stronger than it actually is.

Within a corporate level inventory, consistently separating FLAG emissions within Scope 3 improves transparency, avoids misleading pictures of progress, and enables more comparable and credible reporting across companies and sectors. To do this, a value chain perspective is needed to ensure all FLAG emissions are accounted across upstream and downstream activities, in order to avoid the risk of them being lost into broader corporate emissions totals, making it difficult to apply removals appropriately or to reflect the distinct mitigation dynamics of land-based systems. This approach is especially important given the limited and evolving guidance on corporate-level inventories for agriculture, forestry, and other land-use (AFOLU) activities.  

At the product level, the distinction becomes even more critical. For many products, particularly agricultural commodities, food, apparel, and bio-based materials, land use change and land management emissions dominate the product's carbon footprint. Without clear FLAG attribution, product claims can become misleading; comparisons across suppliers and materials lose validity, and the climate benefits of bio-based materials or regenerative practices may be obscured. Explicit identification of FLAG emissions  is therefore essential for credible product carbon footprints, meaningful supplier engagement, and alignment between product level claims and corporate transition strategies. 

 What is Science Based Targets initiative framework for Forest, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) 

The Science Based Targets initiative framework for Forest, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) guidance provides a dedicated framework for setting science-based targets that address emissions and removals from forests, land, and agriculture, alongside a company’s near-term and long-term climate targets. It clarifies which emissions fall within the FLAG boundary, how land-based emissions and removals should be accounted for, and how companies are expected to demonstrate progress over time in a way that reflects the biological and physical realities of land systems. 

Under the SBTi FLAG, companies are required to set a FLAG-specific target separate from other emissions targets when either of these conditions is met: 

  1. Sector-based requirement: Companies operating in SBTi-designated FLAG sectors, including forest and paper products, food production (animal source), food and beverage processing, food and staples retailing, and tobacco. 
  1. Emissions-threshold requirement: Companies in any sector whose FLAG-related emissions exceed 20% of total gross emissions across scopes 1, 2, and 3. This threshold must be assessed on a gross basis and cannot be netted against removals. 

When a FLAG target is required, companies must report emissions and removals across clearly defined categories that reflect distinct land-based processes: 

  • Land-use change emissions: Refers to CO2 released from carbon stock losses due to the conversion of land between land use categories, such as deforestation for cropland expansion. 
  • Land management emissions: Refers to both CO2 and non-CO2 gases arising from practices within the same land-use category, including tillage, cropping systems, livestock management, and rice cultivation. 
  • Carbon storage and removals: Refers to CO2 removed from the atmosphere through biological processes such as photosynthesis and stored in long-lived biogenic carbon pools such as forest biomass and soils. 

 To ensure transparency and comparability, companies setting FLAG targets are expected to provide disaggregated information that enables meaningful interpretation and review. This includes: 

  •  FLAG emissions and removals reported per commodity and per region 
  •  Separation of land-use change and land management emissions 
  •  Separate reporting of CO2 and non-CO2 emissions from land management activities 
  •  Removals reported by commodity, with further disaggregation across scope 1 and scope 3 categories encouraged 

 These reporting expectations align with the GHG Protocol Land Sector Guidance and the SBTi FLAG Annex submission requirements, supporting consistent and credible treatment of land-based emissions across corporate inventories. 

That’s where our new SBTi FLAG feature comes in. 

 SAP Sustainability Footprint Management for SBTi FLAG 

To facilitate detailed external reporting, especially frameworks like SBTi FLAG that require specific categorization of impacts, SAP's Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a powerful multi-impact category feature. This enables you to map calculated impact category results directly to relevant reporting categories, ensuring alignment with SBTi FLAG requirements. 

For this use case, the integration and calculation setup follow the same procedure as described in our "Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management" blog post. For SBTi FLAG, the process utilizes your ERP data to automate activity data collection, map to emission factors for the relevant impact categories, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The critical difference is ensuring that the relevant impact categories for FLAG are selected during the Footprint Inventory setup. 

Here, you'll define the boundaries and specific impact categories to be assessed in your environmental footprint calculation. This step is crucial for FLAG reporting and the following categories must be selected: 

  • Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management 
  • Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions 
  • Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals 

Additionally, Climate Change is always calculated as a mandatory impact category in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management; you can also choose to calculate additional categories, like abiotic resource depletion, in parallel with the FLAG analysis. 

For details, see Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes. 

You also need to ensure the inclusion of impact factors for the relevant categories using the Manage Emission Factors app. Each impact category requires a specific emission/impact factor. When populating either the LCA or Simple Template, input a separate entry for each category, even if they relate to the same product, energy source, or business activity, as they are distinguished by distinct Impact Category IDs. 

For SBTi, you must include the following categories are included via data packages: 

  • Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management (CCFL) 
  • Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions (CLCN) 
  • Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions (CLCLU) 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Emissions (CLCM) 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals (RELM) 

Climate Change (CLCH) impact factors must also be added, as this category is always mandatory in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Consuming apps like Manage Purchase Products Footprints, Model Energy Flows, Manage Waste Footprints, or Manage Business Activities will utilize these factors for relevant calculations. 

For detailed guidance on maintaining emission factors data, see Emission Factors Data. You'll find a table under Impact Categories, listing all categories, including their IDs, dimensions, and indicators. 

Aside from the impact categories being reported, other calculation parameters like master data, energy flow models, and periodic data remain unchanged. This ensures you can effortlessly scale calculations across different impact categories, allowing existing setups to smoothly adapt and include these additions 

For analyzing the calculated footprints, the Footprint Overview app offers a high-level summary of your impact calculation results, while the Corporate Balance app provides a consolidated view of your organization’s environmental performance. The Purchased Products analytics app now allows display of calculated footprints by impact category using a filter option. 

While the initial dashboards emphasize the Climate Change impact category, clicking on them allows for further detailed analysis. See Using the Footprint Overview Application for more information. 

The Corporate Balance app provides an overarching summary of your organization’s environmental performance. For more on viewing organizational emissions, see Using the Corporate Balance Application. 

The Purchased Products analytics app now provides a detailed understanding of the environmental burden associated with specific procured products across all selected impact categories, offering a richer perspective beyond CO2e. For more insights, see Using the Purchased Products Application. 

Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards 

The Impact Categories from Sustainability Footprint Management are designed to be standard-agnostic, serving as building blocks for supporting multiple reporting standards simultaneously. This versatility, however, requires final results to be mapped to the appropriate reporting categories for the chosen standard. The following table illustrates this: 

 

ID 

SAP Impact Categories for Climate Change Group  

SBTi FLAG  

Reporting Categories 

CLCH 

Climate Change  

Not applicable, always calculated 

CLCF 

Fossil GHG Emissions 

n/a 

CCFL 

Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management  

Land Management (non-CO2 emissions)  

CLCB 

Biogenic CO2 Emissions from Combustion  

n/a 

CLCN 

Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions  

Land Management (non-CO2 emissions) 

CLCLU 

Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions  

Land Use Change Emissions  

CLCLM 

Land Management Biogenic CO2 Emissions  

Land Management (CO2 emissions) 

RELM 

Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals 

Carbon Removals and Storage  

RECCS 

Technological GHG Removal by Direct Capture of Industrial Emissions  

n/a 

REDCC 

Technological GHG Removal by Direct Air Capture  

n/a 

REPCC 

Product Biogenic CO2 Uptake  

n/a

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud: How can I compare variable values?
entry.content:
Hello all,

in SAC I use BW live connection within a story. To read the value of a variable 0S_CUS I use:

var cust = Chart_59.getDataSource().getVariableValues("0S_CUS")[0];

 Then I try to compare the value of variable "cust". Why: I would like to hide some pages in my SAC story if the customer number is greater than 10000000. The infoobject for variable 0S_CUS is 0CUSTOMER (data type: CHAR, length 10).

But this is not working:

var border = "0010000000";
if (cust > border) {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", false);
} else {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", true);
}

The variable 0S_CUS is a select-option but we pre-fill it with only one value. 

The error is: auto-type conversion isn't supported.

Thanks for your help!

entry.title: A simplified approach to choosing between S/4HANA Public Cloud vs S/4HANA Private Cloud
entry.content:
One of the fundamental decisions that organisations are facing as they plan their transition to Cloud ERP, is the deployment option to choose. In SAP terms the question becomes: Would S/4HANA Public Cloud or S/4HANA Private Cloud be the better choice?

At high level, S/4HANA Public Cloud is a "ready-to-run" solution prioritizing standardization and deployment speed, while S/4HANA Private Cloud is a "tailored-to-fit" solution enabling flexibility and customization. In reality, the selection between the two is more complex with different parameters to consider. This article aims to ease the decision process through a simplified approach.

The right deployment option could, and most often should, be subject to a series of workshops and careful assessment of an organisation's specific needs. Still, experience from customer engagements has enabled me to develop a simplified approach which helps provide initial steering.

Overall, where possible, S/4HANA Public Cloud should be the ultimate destination. This due to its unique qualities, including faster access to innovation, a simpler Cloud operating model and reduced Total Cost of Ownership (TCO). On the flip side, Public Cloud also comes with limitations as compared to S/4HANA Private Cloud. These include a narrower implementation scope, reduced system control and the need to leave customisations and certain data behind.

To simplify the decision, as a rule of thumb an organisation should opt for S/4HANA Public Cloud if the following three elements match their needs:

  • S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation scope. Public Cloud offers  broad functionality covering the needs of most organizations and is becoming constantly richer in scope. Still, some functionality such as industry-specific scenarios may be unique to Private Cloud. The way to confirm that Public Cloud vs Private Cloud is fit for purpose is by completing the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment in collaboration with SAP or your Partner.
  • New implementation as migration option. A migration to Public Cloud can be completed only via a new implementation, while a migration to Private Cloud can also be completed via a system conversion or Selective Data transition for organisations on a legacy SAP ERP system. If you are new to SAP, then a new implementation is your clear way forward. If you are moving from a legacy SAP ERP system though, then it is key to validate that a new implementation is right for you. A new implementation requires that custom code and custom processes from your legacy SAP ERP system are left behind - which could actually be an opportunity for moving to a Clean Core and reinventing business processes using SAP's Best Practices. A new implementation also requires that previous transactional data aka closed items are left behind e.g. archived, otherwise maintained in the legacy ERP system (online as read-only or offline as a backup/image). Unless there is a specific need to bring closed items to the new Cloud ERP environment, leaving these behind helps run a lighter, easier to maintain and more cost-efficient system.
  • Public Cloud Operating model. Public Cloud is equivalent to SaaS, as opposed to Private Cloud which is similar to IaaS/PaaS. This means that Public Cloud is highly standardised, enabling rapid innovation at a lower TCO, offering a Clean Core and SAP‑controlled operations and allowing the customer to focus on what matters to them most. It comes with Application Management Services included, therefore, among others, SAP is taking care of  application management including release updates and Middleware. Still, in Public Cloud, extensibility options are limited (classic ABAP extensibility not possible), the customer has no control over release upgrades (these are mandatory without the option to postpone and with a time-restricted regression testing window), and has no control over infrastructure choices either (no Hyperscaler selection). If the organisation has a particular requirement for any of these or for an overall operating model of shared responsibility with SAP, then Private Cloud might be better suited.

    While the above three elements focus mostly on the technical aspects of the deployment option decision, it comes without saying that the company's culture is also a major decisive factor. The appetite to reimagine processes and outsource a large part of IT operations to the software vendor while re-focusing on innovation activities, are of paramount importance for a Public Cloud deployment.

    All that said, the value and fit of Private Cloud for certain organisations should not be overlooked. Many enterprises, especially those with regulatory constraints, multi‑layered integrations, high customisation, heavy data volumes, or deep industry-specific implementation scope, continue to find Private Cloud more practical and in cases the only suitable option.

    To summarise, if you are an organisation planning a transition to SAP’s Cloud ERP and considering your deployment option, your actionable next steps are as follows: complete the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment to confirm whether the scope of S/4HANA Public Cloud matches your functionality needs, evaluate whether a new implementation vs system conversion is fit for purpose, and assess whether the Public Cloud operating model suits you. If the answer to all three questions is yes, and you establish the right company culture, then lead with S/4HANA Public Cloud. Otherwise, in case of unique requirements and a more complex landscape, S/4HANA Private Cloud might be a better fit. 

    Disclaimer: The approach suggested in this article reflects my views based on experience from working with different organizations, rather than SAP's official views. It aims to provide simplified guidelines and initial steering, but does not replace the need for more thorough assessment.

entry.title: Re: exchange rate P for standard cost accounting
entry.content:
Dear @makoto_kasuya91,

In Public Cloud a material/standard cost estimate will not use exchange rate type P just because you maintained rates for type P. You must also ensure that product costing is actually selecting exchange rate type P via the planning/category logic used by the valuation variant

Points to check:

Point 1.

In Public Cloud the exchange rate type for material cost estimate / costing run is determined from the Planning Category and its mapping to an exchange rate type. SAP documents the logic as:

  • Get exchange rate type from Planning Category PLN, configured in 101970 Maintain Category for Planning
  • If nothing is found, system falls back to exchange rate type P

So if you see M being used, it usually means your PLN planning category is mapped to M or you are looking at a different conversion, see point 4

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3667170

Point 2.

In your CBC:

  • Open Maintain Category for Planning (101970)

 

  • Locate planning category PLN
  • Ensure Exchange Rate Type = P
  • Save

SAP explicitly points to 101970 as the place where PLN <-> exchange rate type is maintained

SAP Note and SAP Help below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3513695

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3482860

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/72041b59d4d6413f9c8cdf92bc2ccc7e.html

Summary:

  1. In CBC: 101970, confirm PLN ->P mapping
  2. In Currency Exchange Rates app maintain type P rates for all required currency pairs and for the date used by the cost estimate
  3. Re-run the cost estimate. Existing saved estimates won’t retroactively recalculate

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit – Migrate Directly from SAP System – The Transfer List
entry.content:
Hi all, 

The migration approach Migrate Data Directly from SAP System uses APIs to write data to the SAP S/4HANA target system.

The source data is passed to the parameters of the target API, and the API uses that data to create data in the target SAP S/4HANA system. However, this data can be first modified by field mapping rules (such as mapping rules or source code rules).

Until now, it was not possible to view the exact data that the API uses to create data in the target SAP S/4HANA system.

In the Migrate Your Data app, you can now use the transfer list to view the data that the target API uses to create data in SAP S/4HANA, including the results of all used mapping rules.

Viewing the transfer list can be beneficial if you want to troubleshoot the simulation or migration process. For example, you can analyze the transfer list to determine whether an issue occurs with the target API or if it is a structure or field mapping issue. 

 Where can I find the transfer list?

The transfer list is available with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition 2602.

In the Migrate Your Data app, navigate to the Migration Object Instances screen, select the relevant migration object instance and then choose the Transfer List button.

Note that this feature is only available for the migration approach Migrate Data Directly from SAP System. 

Once the simulation process or migration process is complete for a migration object instance, you can view the transfer list for that instance. If a migration object has multiple transfer steps, a transfer list will be available for each processed step.  

Example

On the Transfer List screen, you can see instance ZRH0000011 for the migration object Customer. This migration object has four transfer steps. The first step CMD_MIG_BP_CVI_CREATE has been simulated successfully for the instance. This means that the transfer list is available for this step. On the left-hand side of the screen, you can view detailed information about the import parameters of step API CMD_MIG_BP_CVI_CREATE.

If you select an import parameter, the system displays the input data for the parameter on the right-hand side of the screen.  

You can use this information, for example, to determine whether an issue occurs with the target API or if it is a structure or field mapping issue.  

We are happy to hear your feedback!  

All the best for your project! 

Philipp

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere Space and Lifecycle Management

entry.title: Can ExcelAdapter Handle Custom Path in SAP PaPM Cloud integration?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!😊

In the earlier SAP Community blogpost SAP PaPM Cloud Integration with Microsoft Excel, we looked at how SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud leverages HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI) with the ExcelAdapter to consume Excel files.

By default, ExcelAdapter only looks for files in the <DPAGENT_DIR>/excel folder. This setup is OK most of the time but what happens when the business wants to make some changes in the location of their Excel files… may it be because of the main drive running out of storage space or reorganizing the folder structure or a cleaner setup. Suddenly, the setup feels more like a limitation than a convenience.

And here’s the catch: if you try to point the Remote Source Configuration to a custom folder, you’ll hit an error just like in the screenshot below.

Does that mean you're stuck on using the default directory? Not quite because we have a workaround. The trick is to use a symbolic link (symlink). In this workaround, the ExcelAdapter will think that it will pull the Excel files from <DPAGENT_DIR>/excel, but in reality, your files are located in other directory.

Let's break it down on how we can achieve this:

Prerequisites:

  • You have an Administrator access in the OS
  • Ensure that the DP Agent Service User have access to the directory to avoid any issue as per SAP Note 3303503

For Windows:

1. Open command prompt as Administrator using the DP Agent Service User and go to <DPAGENT_DIR> directory

2. Enter command: mklink /D excel <Target Directory where your Excel Files are Stored>

For Linux/Unix:

Use the ln-s command: 

ln -s <Target Directory where Excel Files are Stored> <DPAGENT_DIR>/excel

This workaround gives you the flexibility to scale storage, keep things tidy, and adapt to changing business needs—all while staying within ExcelAdapter’s rules.

Have you tried this workaround yourself? Share your story in the comments. 😊

entry.title: Re: entries of 2l and ol ledger difference
entry.content:
Dear all,

SAP S/4HANA behaves this way and, in general, it does not require a correction but rather an overall reconciliation and configuration check.

Ledgers 0L and 2L for the same material and company code are valuated independently. Differences in currency types, exchange rates, Material Ledger price calculation, or rounding can lead to small amount variances.

To address this overall, you should:

  1. Check the currency configuration of the ledgers
    Confirm the currency types and exchange rate types assigned to 0L and 2L. If the business requires identical valuation, the ledger design must be aligned accordingly.
  2. Analyze Material Ledger prices per ledger
    Review prices and settlements per ledger (price and FX differences). If actual costing is active, such differences are expected and correct.
  3. Review rounding impacts
    Small differences may result from rounding at line-item or ledger level and should be reconciled rather than adjusted.

Please feel free to reach out if the differences are material or increasing over time.

Regards

Maciej

entry.title: SAP Task Center Updates: Global Settings in the Administration App
entry.content:
In this series of blog posts, we’ll walk you through the latest updates in the SAP Task Center Administration app, each one designed to simplify the administrative experience and save valuable time.  

Today, we’re focusing on one of the most exciting updates, the new Global Settings tab, which significantly enhances the way administrators manage global configurations for the SAP Task Center Web app.  

The Purpose of Global Settings in SAP Task Center

Global settings are essential for maintaining consistency in SAP Task Center. They allow administrators to manage key configurations that apply to all task providers, ensuring uniformity across the SAP Task Center Web app, and contribute to a unified user experience across all task providers. These settings impact things like supported languages, enablement of the Outbox feature, and the URL used in email notifications. 

The Old Process of Updating Global Settings

Before the introduction of the Global Settings tab, administrators had to manage the global settings destination in the SAP BTP cockpit. This meant navigating to the Cloud Foundry subaccount, locating the Task_Center_global_settings destination, and updating specific values, according to the documentation. Any corrections required repeating the entire process, making it time-consuming and error prone.

The New Global Settings Tab

Now, with the introduction of the Global Settings tab in the SAP Task Center Admin app, administrators can manage these settings more easily and efficiently. The new process has been designed to save time and reduce complexity, allowing administrators to focus on higher-priority tasks.

  1. Centralized Management 
    The Global Settings tab is now located directly within the SAP Task Center Administration app, providing a single, central place for administrators to access and maintain all global settings for all task providers.
  2. Seamless Integration with SAP BTP
    While the Task_Center_global_settings destination is still necessary, it can now be managed directly from the Global Settings tab in the Admin app. Any changes made in the Global Settings tab are automatically synced with the destination in the SAP BTP cockpit, ensuring consistency without any extra manual effort.
    If you haven’t set up SAP Task Center yet, we recommend following the automatic setup, so all destinations, including Task_Center_global_settings, are created for you by the booster. This way you can directly update respective properties from the Global Settings tab. 
  3. Simplified Workflow
    Administrators can configure and validate global settings more quickly, with fewer steps and less context switching. Built-in validation immediately highlights configuration issues, helping prevent errors, reduce trial-and-error, and ensuring that changes are correct before they take effect.

Interested in the UI? Take a look at the Global Settings tab.

This is an overview of the newly introduced Global Settings tab in the SAP Task Center Administration app.

The following demo shows how global settings can be configured directly in the SAP Task Center Administration app.

 

This update not only simplifies the administration tasks but also provides a more intuitive user experience that reduces errors and saves valuable time of the SAP Task Center administrators.

In our upcoming posts, we will cover other exciting updates to the SAP Task Center Administration app.

Stay tuned and stay efficient,

Your SAP Task Center Team

entry.title: Enabling External Workflows for Documents in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Summary

Beside the already available approval procedure available for documents, we’re excited to introduce external workflow integration for Documents in SAP Cloud ALM, enabling organizations to seamlessly connect document management with powerful workflow and approval solutions such as SAP Build Process Automation (BPA).

From Document to Approval – Automatically

When working with documents in SAP Cloud ALM, approvals are often a critical step. With external workflow integration enabled, a custom workflow is automatically triggered as soon as a user selects “Start Approval” in the Documents app.

Behind the scenes, SAP Cloud ALM hands over the approval request to SAP Build Process Automation, where approvers receive their tasks directly in BPA My Inbox.

 The model below illustrates the operational flow and overall functionality.

 

Seamless approval state synchronization

The integration ensures that document approval states in SAP Cloud ALM always reflect the current approval situation:

  • Approval Pending→ Document status is set to In Review, the document content and external file cannot be edited
  • Approved → Document status is automatically updated to Released
  • Rejected → Document remains In Progress, ready for rework

This tight synchronization removes manual updates, reduces errors, and ensures compliance across teams and projects.

Flexible, customizable workflows

The approval process is fully customizable in SAP Build Process Automation. Organizations can design workflows that include:

  • One or multiple approvers
  • Email notifications
  • Parallel or sequential approvals
  • Additional logic and conditions based on document type or document tagging

Once designed, the workflow is deployed and connected to SAP Cloud ALM using standard APIs and destinations—no custom coding required.

Configuration

Configuration prerequisites

  • SAP Build Process Automation subscription and the corresponding service instance (including service key) are available.

For more information, see Subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation.

  • SAP Cloud ALM has been provisioned and a Cloud ALM API service instance has been created (including service key)

For more information on how to create a Cloud ALM API service instance, see Enabling SAP Cloud ALM API.

Configuration Overview

1) Create destination from SAP Cloud ALM to SAP Build Process Automation and backwards

Log on to your SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) subaccount where your SAP Cloud ALM tenant is provisioned. Navigate to Connectivity -> Destinations and create a destination with the following parameter:

Parameter Name

Value

Type

HTTP

URL

https://<url>/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances
<url> = URL from the section endpoints -> api of the BPA instance service key

Proxy Type

Internet

Authentication

OAuth2ClientCredentials

Client ID

section uaa->clientid of the BPA instance service key

Client Secret

section uaa->clientsecret of the BPA instance service key

Token Service URL Type

dedicated

Token Service URL

https://<tenant>.authentication.<domain>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
for <tenant> and <domain>, please refer to the URL from the section uaa->url of the BPA instance service key

Add the following additional properties to the destination:

  • sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true
  • sap.processautomation.enabled = true

You can find more information about using the Destination Editor in the Cockpit in Using the Destinations Editor in the Cockpit.

To use this destination in your project, you must add it to your SAP Business Process Automation tenant. Use the Destinations App in the Control Tower.

For further information about managing destinations, see Manage Destinations.

2) Define workflow in SAP Build Process Automation

The following is an example of an approval workflow with an email notification sent to the approver(s) and initiating user of the workflow:

You can download a default workflow as a sample from the link below and import it into your SAP Build Process Automation tenant.

Sample Document Approval Workflow (link)

By extending this default case, you can use a sample workflow with built-in multi-step approval logic. In this workflow, all reviewers are processed sequentially, and every reviewer must approve for the process to continue. You can find this sample here: Sample Document Approval Workflow - exp. multiple level approval

An example demonstrating how to use script tasks to route approvals to reviewers based on document type or tags is available here: Sample Document Approval Workflow - exp. document tag/type routing 

In the Project Properties (available on the project Overview page) create an environment variable. Assign a name and set the type to Destination.

After completing your workflow edits, release the workflow. To make it usable, switch to the released version and choose Deploy.

You will be asked to select an environment. Use the Public Environment.

For more information about environments, see following link.

In the final step, map the Cloud ALM API destination (from SAP Build Process Automation to Cloud ALM) to the environment variable. Use the Destination created in Step 2.

3) Create workflow subscription in SAP Cloud ALM

Create a webhook in External API Management

Log on to your SAP Cloud ALM tenant and navigate to External API Management.

Go to Webhooks Management and choose Add new webhook.

Enter the following data:

Ext Resource Type

BTP Destination

Other

You can find the <destinationName> in the BTP Cockpit where the destination was created in Step 1.

Create a Mapping

Navigate to Mappings Management and choose Add New Mapping.

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name

Value

Description

<any description> (identifier to map to the subscription)

Version

REST API v1

Source

SAP Cloud ALM

Destination

SAP Build Process Automation

Download the example mapping HERE and copy it into your mapping rules. Adjust the mapping as required. Ensure that the request context matches the input parameters of your workflow. Otherwise, conflicts may occur.

The following document attributes are available:

Create a User Variable.

To obtain the <workflowId>, log on to your SAP Build Process Automation tenant,navigate to Control Tower -> Environments, select the environment where the workflow is deployed, then go to Processes and Workflows, select your workflow and copy the ID.

To obtain the <environmentId>, log on to your SAP Build Process Automation tenant, navigate to Control Tower -> Environments, select the environment where the workflow is deployed and copy the ID.

4) Assign the Workflow Subscription to a Project

Navigate to a project where you want to use the Document workflow. Open the Subscriptions tab and assign the created workflow subscription to the Document entity:

You are now able to execute test approvals for Documents in SAP Cloud ALM using SAP Build Process Automation.

entry.title: SAP Commerce Cloud Q4 ‘25 Release Highlights
entry.content:
As we closed out 2025, SAP Commerce Cloud continued its momentum with a powerful set of innovations designed to deliver connected, trusted, and intelligent commerce experiences that drive profitable growth.​ 

Q4 2025 brought impactful enhancements across commerce, data, AI, fulfillment, and user experience—combined with standout performance results from Cyber Week and recognition once again in the Gartner® Magic Quadrant™. 

Let’s dive into the top updates from Q4 2025. Join our Q4 2025 Release Highlights webcast and the tech-focused update webcast to stay updated on our latest advancements. 

Learn more about the entire SAP Customer Experience portfolio and the impact of agentic AI.

SAP Commerce Cloud named Leader in Gartner Magic Quadrant for Digital Commerce for 11th year in a row 

SAP has proudly been named a Leader in the 2025 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Digital Commerce. SAP remains the only vendor consistently recognized 11 times since 2014. 

This continued leadership reflects SAP Commerce Cloud’s ability to help organizations scale, innovate, and drive profitable growth in an increasingly competitive market. Key differentiators that set SAP Commerce Cloud apart include its robust B2B selfservice portal with native ERP integration, its broad enterprisegrade capabilities, and its proven support for complex and sophisticated business models. 

SAP Commerce Cloud - Cyber Week Results 

SAP Commerce Cloud delivered outstanding results again during the recent Cyber Week The platform supported $17.8 billion in Gross Merchandise Value (GMV), a 40% year over year increase, and reached a peak throughput of $2.3 billion GMV per minute with 11,000 orders processed per minute. Impressively, all of this was achieved with 100% uptime, underscoring the reliability and resilience of the platform during the highest demand period of the year. These results highlight the strength of SAP Commerce Cloud in helping customers scale to meet shopper expectations during critical moments. 

With agentic AI reshaping how customers discover and shop, explore why “2025 is the Last Year Online Shopping Starts with a Search Bar, Not a Sentence.” 

 

Accelerating Customer Value with Enterprise Grade AI Agents 
 
As agentic AI becomes increasingly central to commerce, SAP is expanding its portfolio of intelligent, task‑oriented agents designed to improve engagement, streamline operations, and enhance service at every stage of the customer journey.  

Below are the latest updates to our AI agent capabilities, beginning with the Digital Service Agent. 

The Digital Service Agent elevates customer self service by delivering fast, accurate support powered by enterprise specific knowledge and data sources. It efficiently resolves complex customer inquiries and can seamlessly hand off conversations to human agents whenever deeper assistance is required, ensuring a smooth and consistent service experience. 
 

Working in tandem with the AI Shopping Agent, the Digital Service Agent unlocks new, end to end use cases that provide even greater value. Together, these agents offer customers unified, intelligent assistance across the entire shopping journey—from initial product exploration to post purchase support—improving satisfaction while reducing operational effort. 

Digital Service Agent 

 

Create custom AI agents with Joule Studio AI agent bulder 

 
With the new Joule Studio AI agent builder, you can now create AI agents for SAP Customer Experience applications that retrieve information, execute tasks, and perform autonomous actions using enterprise data from SAP Customer Experience and SAP Knowledge Graph. For example, you can build a returns processing agent that automatically initiates return execution based on insights and recommendations generated by the AI.

Joule Studio, part of SAP Build, offers a powerful lowcode and nocode environment that enables developers to extend Joule capabilities and orchestrate business workflows across both SAP and non SAP systems. From here, teams can easily build, test, and deploy AI agents to enhance operational efficiency and deliver more intelligent customer experiences. 
 
Learn how to activate Joule Studio and start building, testing, and deploying AI Agents. 

 

Joule Studio AI agent builder

 

Turn Live Commerce Data into a Competitive Advantage 

SAP Commerce Cloud Dashboards (Graph Analytics Micro App), is an SAP-certified micro app that is built on SAP Business Technology Platform, providing businesses with instant access to real-time operational insights without the need for complex setup or custom development.  

 

This lightweight yet powerful micro app delivers dynamic dashboards that visualize key commerce metrics including revenue, orders, returns, repeat purchase rates, top performingproducts, and more. By centralizing these insights in a single, intuitive interface, teams can make faster and more informed decisions based on live data. With clearer visibility into trends and performance drivers, businesses can identify growth opportunities, optimize promotions and product strategies, and ultimately boost revenue through data-driven decision making. 

 

Enhance Security and Efficiency with User Management via Cloud Portal API 

User Management via Cloud Portal API enables organizations to manage user roles for an SAP Commerce Cloud environment. By exposing user and role management capabilities through secure APIs, teams can integrate these operations directly into their existing CI/CD and enterprise workflows. This reduces repetitive configuration steps and enhances security and compliance through audit ready role assignments and changes.  

 

Resilient Backup and Recovery with Quick Data Backup 

Quick Data Backup simplifies database protection by providing near-instant backup capabilities and 35-day point in- time recovery across development, stage, and production environments. This solution ensures that businesses can safeguard critical data with confidence and can significantly minimize downtime during incidents. The feature is designed for seamless compatibility with existing workflows, reducing operational friction. With Quick Data Backup, teams gain a reliable, efficient, and resilient foundation for data protection across the entire Commerce Cloud landscape. 

 

Fast In-Memory Cart for High Traffic Commerce 

The Rapid Cart Calculation capability introduces a major performance boost to SAP Commerce Cloud by processing all price and cart calculations directly in server memory. This delivers exceptionally fast response times, especially for high traffic storefronts and scenarios such as product detail page price checks. The in-memory cart not only enhances the customer experience with instant, seamless cart interactions but also significantly reduces backend load, improving overall system scalability and stability. 

 

 This approach supports massive throughput—enabling millions of cart calculation requests per hour—ensuring that even the most demanding commerce environments can maintainconsistent performance during major events like flash sales, seasonal peaks, and promotional campaigns. 

 

Optimize Delivery Performance with Bringg 

Bringg Delivery Management Integrates with SAP Order Management to streamline fulfillment and optimize last mile delivery. With this integration, businesses can offer flexible delivery options, providing customers with real-time tracking updates and proactive notifications across channels. Operationally, automated dispatching reduces manual effort and helps ensure on time delivery, even during peak periods. The result is a faster, more reliable delivery experience that boosts customer satisfaction while improving efficiency and margins. 

 

Assess Your Readiness to Headless Commerce 

The Storefront Maturity Assessment, a free self-service online tool, enables customers to evaluate their organization’s readiness to transition from Accelerator-based storefronts to modern headless architectures. The tool generates personalized, best practice recommendations tailored to each customer’s starting point, helping teams understand where they excel and where additional preparation or alignment is needed. 

 

 This shared assessment framework allows business and technical stakeholders to align priorities and create a unified transformation roadmap. With actionable insights into capability gaps and readiness markers, organizations can accelerate their headless adoption journey, improve pipeline planning, and ultimately enhance the quality and predictability of their digital transformation initiatives.  

For more details on the above release features, check out the following resources: 

  • SAP Commerce Cloud Release Ready Kit 
  • Performance Optimization Best Practices 
  • SAP Commerce Cloud update cycle 
  • SAP Commerce Cloud Release Navigator single access point to release content 
  • Sign up for Q4 2025 SAP Commerce Cloud release recap webcast 
  • Replay SAP Commerce Cloud: Year in Review and 2026 Roadmap webcast 

 

SAP Help Portal 

  • SAP Commerce Cloud What’s New 

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Commerce Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: Re: How to see Queue errors in SXMB_MONI
entry.content:
Below are the options to identify the error

  • Execute transaction SMQ1 & SMQ2. Look for the queue name related to your interface (often starts with XBQ* or XBT*). If the message is stuck, you’ll see entries with status “SYSFAIL” or “READY.”
  • Open the message ID → go to Technical Details → Message Log. Sometimes the error is hidden in the log (e.g., “No COMMIT issued,” “Receiver channel error,” “Mapping failed”).
  • Go to transaction SLG1 with object XMB or XI. Enter the message ID → you may see more detailed error text.
  • If this is not pure ABAP but involves the Adapter Engine, check the Adapter Engine message log in the Integration Engine or NWA. Errors there won’t show in ST22.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management 2602 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
1.  Launch Automatic Matching Manually (CIM-2465)

You can now trigger automatic matching directly from the Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally app while editing a draft invoice. With the new "Match Automatically" button, you can quickly validate invoice data against purchase orders or receipts without leaving your workflow.

Once you have chosen Match Automatically, you can determine which line items will be considered when you launch the automatic matching:

  • All items
  • Non-manually assigned items
  • Unassigned items
  • Items with errors

Any existing posting data that is provided for the selected line items will be deleted and recreated through the automatic matching. The supplier invoice will be saved and move to the process step Reference Object Matching.

Example of the User Interface

The screenshot below shows a new Match Automatically button along with the options for automatic matching in the Manage:

Benefits:

  • Saves time: Eliminate the need to navigate between screens to initiate matching.
  • Improves accuracy: Reduce errors by automating the validation process.
  • Boosts efficiency: Speed up invoice approvals with fewer manual steps.

This enhancement helps you to process invoices faster while maintaining compliance and control.

2.  Decision Tables in Configure Assignment Group Rules App (CIM-2861)

Managing invoice assignments just got smarter. With this release, the Configure Assignment Group Rules app now supports Decision Tables, making it easier to define and apply complex routing rules.

When creating a variant in the Configure Assignment Group Rules app, you can now select Decision Table in the Assignment Group/User Rule field within the Step Configuration tab. Below are the available input parameter combinations for different decision tables. Assignment groups and users are the output:

  • Company Code and WBS Element
  • Company Code and Cost Center
  • Company Code, Invoicing Party, and Gross Amount
  • Company Code and G/L Account
  • Commodity Code 

Example of the User Interface

The figure below shows the list of decision tables available in the Configure Decision Tables app for the assignment group and user determination:

Why it matters:

  • Simplified rule configuration:  Decision tables provide a clear, structured way to define assignment rules, reducing manual effort and minimizing errors.
  • Enhanced flexibility:  Use decision tables directly in the Assignment Group/User Rule field under the Step Configuration tab when setting up variants.
  • Improved accuracy:  Ensure invoices are routed to the right teams or users based on predefined conditions, improving processing speed and compliance.

This feature empowers your finance and procurement teams to handle exceptions and approvals more efficiently, reducing bottlenecks and accelerating invoice processing.

3.  Assignment Group/User determined by Custom Logic in the Configure Assignment Group Rules app (CIM-1759)

With this release, it is possible to determine the assignment group or user, or a combination of both, using custom logic.

In the Configure Assignment Group Rules app, you now have the option to choose an assignment group/user rule. This is available in the new Assignment Group/User Rule field in the Step Configuration tab.

If you choose Assignment Group/User Determined by Custom Logic in this field, it allows you to determine the assignment group or user of a step without specifying them during variant creation. The determination is done outside the app via an API.

Example of the User Interface

The screenshot below shows the Step Configuration tab in the Configure Assignment Group Rules app:

4.  Simulation of Workflow Steps before Submission of Invoice (CIM-1759)

The latest release of SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management introduces exciting new features designed to simplify workflows, reduce errors, and improve collaboration between finance teams and suppliers. 

Key Benefits of this Feature:

  • Enhanced Transparency – See the full approval path upfront, so there are no surprises.
  • Proactive Issue Resolution – Spot potential delays or missing approvals before submission.
  • Improved Efficiency – Reduce back-and-forth by ensuring invoices follow the correct workflow from the start.

Changes to the User Interface

The screenshot below shows tab when there is no request for information available and an approval workflow is yet to start:

The next screenshot shows the tab when a request for information has started but an approval workflow is yet to start:

 The final screenshot below shows the tab when all the workflows have started:

This enhancement is just one way we’re making invoice management smarter and more intuitive for our customers.

5.  New Field for Invoice Management (CIM-3034)

A new Contact Person field has been added to the invoice detail page, allowing users to designate a responsible individual for managing and approving invoices. This feature enhances accountability and streamlines the invoice approval process, ensuring timely payments and efficient workflow management.

This field is hidden by default. You can control its visibility using the Configure Business Data Scope app. For more information, see About Field Control. You can use the value help to enter a name in this field.

You can also set the contact person as an approver of an invoice. To do this, select Contact Person for The Invoice in the Agent Determination Rule field of the Step Configuration tab.  This applies when creating a variant or adding a step in an existing variant in the Manage Workflows for Supplier Invoice Approval app.

In addition, you can configure automatic allocation of a supplier invoice to the name entered. To achieve this, select Contact Person for the Invoice in the Assignment Group/User Rule field of the Step Configuration tab. This applies when creating a variant or adding a step in an existing variant in the Configure Assignment Group Rules app.  

A new Contact Person filter is also added to the invoice list page to filter the invoices based on it. This filter and the column are not available by default. See Adapting Filters and Creating Variants for more information on how to show or hide the filters and the columns.  Any update made in this new field is recorded in the activity log.

Changes to the User Interface

The screenshot below shows you the Contact Person field:

Benefits:

  • Enhanced accountability – Designate a specific contact for each invoice, reducing confusion and delays.
  • Streamlined approvals – Faster processing with direct responsibility, leading to timely payments.
  • Improved workflow efficiency – Better tracking and communication for smoother invoice management.

This small but impactful feature helps teams work more effectively, reducing bottlenecks and improving collaboration across finance and procurement teams.

What’s Next?

Stay tuned for more innovations in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management as we continue to enhance automation, visibility, and control in your invoice management processes.

Have questions or want to learn more? Reach out to your SAP representative or explore our help documentation at http://help.sap.com.

Let’s make invoice management simpler, smarter, and faster—together.

Resources:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement and Network
  • What’s New

entry.title: Re: Using different GL to record Receivables
entry.content: You cannot override the recon account at posting time in the Create Outgoing Invoices app; it is always derived from BP master data. Recon accounts are control accounts; they are not meant to be changed frequently. If you need flexibility, consider creating alternative BP master records or using different reconciliation accounts by customer group.

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud: How can I compare variable values?
entry.content:
Hi Nikhil,

The following script works for me:

var cust = Chart_59.getDataSource().getVariableValues("0S_CUS")[0];
var cust_single = cast(Type.SingleVariableValue, cust);
var cust_val = cust_single.value;
var cust_num = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(cust_val);

var border = 10000000;

if (cust_num > border) {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", false);
} else {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", true);
}

Thanks for your help!

Regards,
Yvonne

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM Observability: Instrumenting SAP NetWeaver Java AS with OpenTelemetry
entry.content:
Instrumenting SAP NetWeaver Java AS with OpenTelemetry

This article focuses on configuring OpenTelemetry for SAP NetWeaver Application Server (AS) Java. For additional steps—such as registering a service in SAP Cloud ALM, obtaining API credentials, or setting up the OpenTelemetry Collector—refer to the following blog: observability-for-third-party-components-components-using-sap-cloud-alm.

Prerequisites

Before configuring OpenTelemetry on SAP NetWeaver Java AS:

  1. Download the OpenTelemetry Java Agent.
  2. Copy the agent file to your desired directory.

Steps to Configure via NetWeaver Administrator (NWA)

  1. Access NWA:

    • Open your browser and navigate to: http://<hostname>:<port>/nwa
    • Note: You need administrator privileges to make these changes.

  2. Navigate to Java System Properties:

    • Go to Configuration → Infrastructure → Java System Properties.

  3. Select the Java Server Node:

    • Expand the template name and choose the ID of a Java Server Node.

  4. Add the OpenTelemetry Java Agent:

    • Under Additional VM Parameters, add:
      -javaagent:/<path_to_file>/opentelemetry-javaagent.jar

  5. Configure System VM Parameters:

    • Switch to the System VM Parameters tab and add the following:


      parameter name parameter value
      otel.exporter.otlp.metrics.endpointhttp://demo_otel:4318*
      otel.exporter.otlp.protocolgrpc
      otel.exporter.metrics.exporterotlp
      * - referring to the OTel collector configuration, described on Observability for third party components component... - SAP Community

  6. Repeat for All Java Application Instances:

    • If multiple server nodes exist, specify a unique attribute (e.g., otel.resource.attributes=service.name=JC7-Instance_00).

  7. Save and Restart:

    • Save the settings and restart the system to activate data collection.

  8. Verify Metrics in SAP Cloud ALM:

    • Check the collected metrics in Health Monitoring by selecting the defined "Unspecific Cloud Service" in the scope selector.

 

Collecting OpenTelemetry Logs and Traces

In addition to metrics, you can also collect Java logs and traces, which appear in Integration & Exception Monitoring and Real User Monitoring. To enable this, add the following parameters:

parameter nameparameter value
otel.exporter.logs.exporterotlp
otel.exporter.traces.exporterotlp

Logs & Traces in SAP Cloud ALM

  • Logs: View in Integration & Exception Monitoring.
  • Traces: View in Real User Monitoring.

To view the reported exceptions, launch the Integration & Exception Monitoring.

The request executions and their response times can be analyzed in Real User Monitoring.

 

Conclusion

By following these steps, you can successfully instrument SAP NetWeaver Java AS with OpenTelemetry, enabling comprehensive observability for metrics, logs, and traces in SAP Cloud ALM.

entry.title: Creating value in airlines
entry.content:
MOST PROFITABLE, LARGEST, AND MOST VALUABLE ARILINE

As we travel back from the holidays, or into year-start meetings, it may be a good time to reflect on the companies that make such travel possible. In this case, let’s examine Delta Air Lines’ transformation journey with SAP.

Specifically, let us zoom in on three related areas of transformation:
1. Delta’s strategy of top customer experience, which among other things means on-time flights.
2. Workforce optimization to enable upward mobility for some 100,000 people.
3. Improving financial close, which was historically burdened with significant non-linearity.

These areas of Delta’s evolution show a clear connection between passenger experience, Delta’s own resources, and share- and debt-holders as providers of capital.

Let’s start from the customer excellence.
 
ON-TIME ARRIVAL
You can see the comparison of Delta with other major global airlines: horizontally plotted are percentages of flights with on-time arrival and vertically plotted are the number of flights per year. Delta, with some of the highest number of flights in the world, is constantly improving its on-time arrival statistics and currently stands at 84%. This is an amazing achievement for such a large operation. The accolades from the media and experts are well deserved.

But let’s look at what it took to achieve such operational excellence.

For now, let us focus on the processes part of the equation; we will talk about people soon.
The major reason for delayed flights, apart from the weather, is supplies. Catering, to be more specific. Before Delta embarked on the journey to significantly overhaul its operations, the state of the union was as follows:

  1. Very large operations across the globe… but email communications with the suppliers.
  2. Multiple items of supplies… but some not even recorded in Delta’s inventory system. For example, there were stories of half a million dollars' worth of earbuds and a million dollars' worth of blankets left in various airports without any visibility for Delta’s operational colleagues.

That had to change, and Delta did change them. To support its in-sourcing processes, the company adopted SAP IBP and SAP SAC to enable some 155 locations, 255 suppliers and 8 warehouses worldwide.
As a result of demand sensing and inventory optimization, Delta was able to optimize its catering, including the weight aspect of the supplies (for example, the number of food and beverage items based on the passenger count). This, in turn, led do significant fuel savings, which cumulatively accounted for some $100m cost savings in 2024.

To sum it up, for the first strategic transformation area, not only did Delta improve its on-time arrival KPI but it also removed some costs. This brings us to the people side of the equation…

Workforce mobility
Operational excellence goes hand in hand with the people excellence. Especially when you know that people expenses account for a quarter of your revenue or some $15 billion, and they grow faster than revenues.
The company decided to do a few things:
1. Lower the educational requirements and rather train people on the job.
2. Give people opportunities to advance.
3. Lower the “extra shift costs” where possible.

Why this was critical becomes clear when you look at Delta’s workforce…
Delta’s people represent a very diverse human resource organization, by location, type of job performed, and typical challenges.

So let us, together with Delta, look at one typical employee…
Like many large organizations, Delta sees two significant workforce drivers: Source & Recruit and Enable & Develop.
It’s the second one where the company realized it was missing a lot. Meet Eleanor, a typical high-achiever, who – through her effort on the ground – became a top performer (“red coat” in Delta’s language) but wants to push herself even higher. When Eleanor searched the corporate portal for job opportunities in Finance, some 1,100 results appeared – an impossible number to comprehend and take action on. This is what Delta’s colleagues call the “foggy gap”: the desire to learn and grow is present, but no enabler exists for that.

When the managers considered the traditional approach, they quickly realized its limitations and resulting frustration, both for the employees and for the hiring managers.

Therefore, Delta adopted its own, unique approach: FOCUS ON SKILLS, NOT JOB DESCRIPTION.

During the transformation, Delta created a repository of SKILLS making it available to employee and tying skills the Delta’s HR needs. This enables the employees to focus on what they either have to have to develop, as opposed to searching through numerous job postings and trying to decipher them.  The results of this approach are quite telling.  Half of the managerial positions are filled with experience Delta veterans ensuring upward mobility and job satisfaction, and the central skills repository is easy to maintain and update.

But most important is the overall outcome: employees who feel taken care of by Delta, take good care of the Delta customers.

Now that we have reviewed two strategic initiatives – on time flight arrival and employee mobility – we can look at another challenge Delta faced throughout the years.

 

Nonlinearity
It is January 1. Or April1. Time to close the year or quarter. Yet during this first week of January or April, Delta receives the vast majority of its invoices including from contractors for the previous period. The week is literally flooded with work. For the year close, we are talking about some $30 billion in gross debits! That’s half of the total annual business.

Such contracted services come from different sources, including companies such as Unifi, an approximately $2bn and 40,000 employee strong largest provider of air services in North America. (link)

Services such as plane taxying, cleaning, baggage loading, special needs passenger transportation, tie back to the on-time flight departure and arrival as well, so they are critical to Delta’s strategy...
…and for Delta, such services spell into some $4 billion cost item, i.e., approximately $1bn each quarter.

Before the transformation, most of such reconciliation and postings were manual. To automate this process, Delta utilized SAP HANA as the main source of flight data, coupled it with the AI tools from Blackline, creating a more automatic incoming invoice matching and posting process.

As a result, some 2/3 ds of the accruals became automatic matches, and that trend continues. Overall, this automation significantly lessens the strain of period close and compresses the time to close, freeing oCFO colleagues’ time for higher added value work.

But the amazing by-product of the automation is a much shorter time to publish quarterly reports. Among the major US airlines, Delta is the fastest to file its 10-Qs, the quarterly reports, therefore improving its stance with the share- and debt-holders.

So, the question is, does the market notice all these Delta’s efforts to evolve across the three strategic imperatives?

Recap
The answer is unequivocal yes. Through its incredible journey to improve customer service, create workforce mobility, and combat non-linearity for faster financial close, in the past 5 years, Delta grew its Enterprise Value by 1.4x or at approximately 7.6% CAGR. Delta has become one of the most profitable and the most valuable airline.  I am proud to say that SAP has supported Delta in every step.


*    *     *

Big debt of gratitude to my partners at SAP and, most importantly, to Delta – for being an SAP customer!

entry.title: Creating value in airlines
entry.content:

3. Improving financial close, which was historically burdened with significant non-linearity.
